raw_text:
Brown names 16 March for Budget
 
 Chancellor Gordon Brown will deliver his Budget to the House of Commons on 16 March, the Treasury has announced.
 
 The Budget, likely to be the last before the General Election, will be at about 1230 GMT on that Wednesday, just after Prime Minister's question time. The annual event is when the chancellor outlines the government's taxation and broader economic predictions. The Tories say it is likely the Budget will contain measures to attract votes. The election is expected on 5 May.
 
 Next month's Budget will be Mr Brown's ninth since Labour came to power in 1997. If a May election is called, there could be as little as 18 days between the Budget and the announcement of a date for the election. A shortened Finance Bill would have to be rushed through Parliament with all-party support to allow the Government to continue collecting revenue.
 
 The full Finance Bill, with the Budget measures in it, would then be returned to the Commons after the election, if Labour secures another term in office. Tory shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin said: "We can be sure of two things: the Budget will contain measures to attract votes, and it will not contain the £8 billion of tax rises which independent experts say are inevitable if Labour wins the election." As Mr Brown announced the Budget date in a short ministerial statement, accountancy firm Ernst & Young urged him to put politics aside and focus on the long-term requirements of the economy. "In the Budgets that were given immediately before the last six elections, taxes were cut by the incumbent chancellor and, in many cases, taxes were increased soon after the election result," said Aidan O'Carroll, E&Y's UK head of tax.
llama3.2:1b: Chancellor Gordon Brown will deliver his Budget on March 16 to the House of Commons at about 1230 GMT that Wednesday. The budget is likely to include measures to attract votes and may be followed by a general election in May if Labour secures another term in office, with potentially as little as 18 days between the two events.
llama3.2:3b: Chancellor Gordon Brown will deliver his Budget to Parliament on 16 March at 1230 GMT, likely the last before the General Election expected on 5 May. The Budget is expected to contain measures to attract votes and may include £8 billion in tax rises if Labour wins the election. A shortened Finance Bill could be rushed through Parliament with all-party support to allow continued revenue collection if an early election is called.
gemma2:2b: Chancellor Gordon Brown will deliver his Budget to the House of Commons on March 16th, 2023, shortly after Prime Minister's question time.  The budget is expected to be released before a May election and may contain measures aimed at attracting votes. A shortened Finance Bill would likely need all-party support if the election is called. If a new government is formed following an election, the full Finance Bill with the Budget measures will be presented.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
The Chancellor Gordon Brown will deliver his Budget to the House of Commons on 16 March, likely at around 12:30 PM GMT. The annual event is when the chancellor outlines the government's taxation and broader economic predictions, with potential measures aimed at attracting votes for Labour in the May election. If a May election is called, it could take as little as 18 days between the Budget date and the announcement of an election date. A shortened Finance Bill would need to be rushed through Parliament with all-party support to continue collecting revenue, allowing the Government to continue collecting income tax.

The full Finance Bill would then be returned to the Commons after the May election if Labour secures another term in office. UK Chancellor Jeremy Hunt urged Brown not to let politics take precedence and instead focus on the long-term requirements of the economy.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Chancellor Gordon Brown will deliver his 2015 Budget on March 16, likely as part of a package aimed at attracting votes amid an expected general election in May. The Finance Bill, containing key economic and taxation measures, could be rushed through Parliament with all-party support after the event to allow for continued revenue collection if Labour secures another term.
qwen2.5:3b: Chancellor Gordon Brown has announced that he will deliver his Budget to the House of Commons on 16 March, likely before the General Election on 5 May. This Budget is expected to be Mr Brown’s ninth since Labour came to power in 1997 and could mark a last chance for him as Chancellor before the election. The Budget may include measures aimed at attracting votes, with critics suggesting it will not contain £8 billion of tax rises. Accountancy firm Ernst & Young urged Mr Brown to prioritize long-term economic requirements over political considerations.
opencoder:1.5b:
The output will be a summary of the given text. Here is the summary:

1. Mr Gordon Brown will deliver his Budget to the House of Commons on 16 March.
2. The annual event for the Budget will occur on Wednesday around 12:30 GMT, likely on that day.
3. The full Finance Bill has been returned to the Commons after the election.
4. The Budget includes measures to attract votes and is expected to contain a reduction in tax bills.
5. The full Budget details are announced in a short ministerial statement.
6. The announcement of the Budget date will take place on May 5th, which could result in a delay as more than 18 days have passed since the last six elections. 
7. Tax increases could be imposed if Labour wins the election and there is another term to come for them in office. 
8. Mr Brown has announced the Budget date in a short statement.
9. The announcement of the Budget date will occur on May 5th, which may result in a delay as more than 18 days have passed since the last six elections.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Chancellor Gordon Brown's budget for the upcoming election. Let me read through it carefully.

First sentence: "Brown names 16 March for Budget." That's straightforward—they're delivering a budget on March 16th. The House of Commons will hear it that day.

Next, the Budget is likely before the General Election, around noon local time (GMT). They'll discuss taxes and economy.

The Conservative party says they expect some measures to attract votes, maybe more than usual since they've been running the show for a long time.

In the month of November, this budget was Mr Brown's ninth as Chancellor. If there's an election next May, Labour might have a short Finance Bill rushed through Parliament.

Tory shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin said he can be sure two things: the Budget includes measures to get votes and doesn't include £8 billion in taxes if Labour wins. He urged others to focus on long-term economic needs.

Ernst & Young's head of tax suggested they didn't cut taxes immediately after elections, except when there were big changes. They emphasized that past cuts weren't sustainable anymore because other parties won each election.

So the key points are: budget is before election; Conservative expects some votes, more than usual; previous budgets were as long as Labour terms; potential for a short Finance Bill if election starts May and Labour wins; Letwin's prediction about taxes not increasing if Labour does win. Also, E&Y's warning to focus on economic needs.

I need to make sure the summary captures all that without too much extra fluff.
</think>

Brown delivers hisBudget on March 16th, before the General Election, announcing measures to attract votes. The Conservative party expects some voter attraction in the upcoming election. Brown has been Chancellor for nine months as Chief Executive. If there's an election May, a short Finance Bill might be rushed through Parliament with all-party support. The full Bill will be returned after the election, if Labour secures another term. Tory shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin stated: "We can be sure of two things: the Budget includes measures to attract votes and it won't raise £8 billion in taxes if Labour wins." Ernst & Young advised ignoring politics during the Budget announcement, focusing on economic needs.
tinyllama:1.1b: Summary: The Chancellor Gordon Brown will deliver his Budget to the House of Commons on 16 March, ahead of the General Election. The Budget is likely to contain measures to attract votes and is expected to be announced during Prime Minister's question time. The election is scheduled for 5 May, with a shortened Finance Bill having to be returned to Parliament with all-party support if Labour secures another term in office. The full Finance Bill would then be sent back after the election, and the Budget measures would be expected to contain measures to attract votes. Independent experts predict the £8 billion of tax rises which they say are necessary to fund the government's policies. E&Y urges Mr Brown to put politics aside and focus on long-term economic needs.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Summary: British Prime Minister Gordon Brown is expected to deliver his budget on March 16th, which could be the last budget before the General Election. The annual event is when the chancellor outlines the government's taxation and broader economic predictions. This year's budget will likely contain measures aimed at attracting votes for the upcoming election. A May-elected Labour government may have as little as 18 days between the Budget and an announcement of an election date, which must be done in a shortened Finance Bill. The full Finance Bill containing the budget measures will then be returned to the Commons after the election if Labour secures another term in office.
phi:2.7b: Chancellor Gordon Brown will present his Budget to the House of Commons on 16 March, which is likely to be the last before the General Election on 5 May. The budget will include taxation and economic predictions, with the election expected in May. Mr. Brown's ninth budget has been announced since Labour came into power in 1997. If an early election is called, a Finance Bill would have to be passed quickly to allow revenue collection. Tory shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin said that the Budget will contain measures to attract votes but not increase taxes by £8 billion as recommended by independent experts. Ernst & Young urged Mr Brown to focus on long-term economic requirements and not let politics get in the way of making sound decisions for the economy.

chatgpt-4o-latest: Chancellor Gordon Brown will present the Budget on 16 March, likely the last before the expected 5 May General Election. The Budget will outline taxation and economic forecasts, with the opposition claiming it will include vote-attracting measures while omitting inevitable tax rises. If the election is called, a shortened Finance Bill must be rushed through Parliament to maintain revenue collection, with the full bill returning post-election if Labour wins. Experts urge Brown to prioritize long-term economic needs over political tactics, noting past pre-election tax cuts followed by post-election increases.
stablelm2:1.6b: Chancellor Gordon Brown will present his last Budget before the General Election on March 16th, according to the Treasury. The budget is expected to outline government economic predictions and tax measures, although the Conservatives claim it may include strategies to appeal to voters. If a May election takes place, there could be as few as two days between the Budget announcement and the election date. Brown's ninth Budget since Labour came to power will take place next month if he remains in office, but if Labour wins an election, the full Finance Bill containing the budget measures would return to the Commons after the poll.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
Chancellor Gordon Brown is scheduled to present his Budget to the House of Commons on 16 March at approximately 12:30 PM GMT, following Prime Minister's question time. This marks his ninth Budget since Labour took power in 1997. The Budget is anticipated to be the last before the General Election, scheduled for 5 May. If an election occurs, there may be just 18 days between the Budget and the election announcement. In such a scenario, a condensed Finance Bill would need urgent parliamentary approval to maintain revenue collection.

The Conservatives predict the Budget will include measures intended to sway voters. Tory shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin vowed that the Budget would not entail the predicted £8 billion tax hikes if Labour wins the election. Accountancy firm Ernst & Young advised Brown to prioritize long-term economic needs over political gain, citing historical trends where incumbent chancellors cut taxes before elections and often raised them post-election.
reference: The full Finance Bill, with the Budget measures in it, would then be returned to the Commons after the election, if Labour secures another term in office.If a May election is called, there could be as little as 18 days between the Budget and the announcement of a date for the election.Tory shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin said: "We can be sure of two things: the Budget will contain measures to attract votes, and it will not contain the £8 billion of tax rises which independent experts say are inevitable if Labour wins the election."The Budget, likely to be the last before the General Election, will be at about 1230 GMT on that Wednesday, just after Prime Minister's question time.The Tories say it is likely the Budget will contain measures to attract votes.
